questions.text: Lesions in ….. lead to sensory ataxia-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Posterior column. Lesions in the posterior column of the spinal cord can lead to sensory ataxia. The posterior column is responsible for transmitting proprioceptive information (sensory input about body position and movement) from the periphery to the brain. Damage to this area impairs the ability to sense the position of limbs and body parts, resulting in uncoordinated movements, which is known as sensory ataxia. B. Vermis: The vermis is part of the cerebellum and is involved in coordinating movement, particularly in the trunk and proximal limbs. Damage to the vermis can cause ataxia, but this is primarily motor ataxia, not sensory ataxia. The vermis coordinates movement, but it does not primarily handle sensory information. C. Floculo-nodular lobe: The floculo-nodular lobe of the cerebellum is involved in balance and coordination, particularly in regulating eye movements and posture. Lesions here can lead to problems with balance and equilibrium, but they are not typically associated with sensory ataxia, which is related to a loss of sensory feedback. D. Vestibular apparatus: The vestibular apparatus, located in the inner ear, plays a critical role in maintaining balance and spatial orientation. Lesions here can lead to vertigo, dizziness, and balance issues, but sensory ataxia, which involves difficulty with proprioception and spatial awareness due to loss of sensory input, is not a direct result of vestibular apparatus damage.

questions.text: Flocculonodular lobe of cerebellum is concerned with-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Equilibrium. The flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum is primarily involved in the regulation of equilibrium and balance. It receives input from the vestibular system (which controls balance) and is responsible for coordinating the body's posture and movement in response to changes in equilibrium. The flocculonodular lobe plays a critical role in maintaining stability and coordinating eye movements to preserve balance. B. Co-ordination: While the cerebellum as a whole is responsible for coordinating voluntary movement, the flocculonodular lobe is specifically concerned with balance and equilibrium. Other parts of the cerebellum, such as the anterior and posterior lobes, are more involved in the coordination of voluntary muscle movements and fine motor control. C. Baroreception: Baroreception refers to the detection of changes in blood pressure, which is a function of baroreceptors located in the carotid sinus and aortic arch. This is not a role of the cerebellum or the flocculonodular lobe, which are involved in motor control and equilibrium. D. Chemoreception: Chemoreception involves the detection of chemical stimuli, such as oxygen levels, pH, and gases, which is typically the function of specialized receptors in the carotid body and aortic body, not the cerebellum. The cerebellum is not involved in chemoreception, which pertains more to the regulation of respiratory and circulatory functions.

Correct Answer (C) Flocculonodular lobe of cerebellum. The vestibular fibers primarily relay in the flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum, which is responsible for processing information related to balance and equilibrium. The vestibular system, which detects changes in head position and movement, sends signals to this part of the cerebellum to help maintain balance and coordinate eye movements during motion. A. Vermis: The vermis of the cerebellum is involved in coordinating movement, particularly in the axial muscles (the muscles of the trunk and neck), but it is not the primary site for relaying vestibular information. The flocculonodular lobe has a more direct role in processing vestibular inputs. B. Lateral geniculate body: The lateral geniculate body is part of the thalamus and is involved in relaying visual information from the retina to the visual cortex. It does not process vestibular information, which is more related to balance and spatial orientation. D. Auditory cortex: The auditory cortex processes sound information, which is relayed from the cochlea via the auditory pathways. It is not involved in the relay of vestibular information. The vestibular system is primarily associated with the cerebellum, not the auditory pathways.

choices.text: Planning and programming of voluntary movements

questions.text: The function of the neocerebellum are-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Planning and programming of voluntary movements. The neocerebellum, also known as the cerebrocerebellum, is primarily involved in the planning and programming of voluntary movements. It receives inputs from the cerebral cortex via the pontine nuclei and is involved in the coordination of fine, voluntary movements. It helps in the execution of complex movements and the timing of those movements, ensuring they are smooth and well-coordinated. This function is crucial for activities that require precise control, such as playing a musical instrument or writing. A. Maintenance of equilibrium: The maintenance of equilibrium is primarily handled by the vestibulocerebellum, which is part of the cerebellum responsible for balance and posture. This region receives input from the inner ear's vestibular system and helps maintain the body's balance during movement. The neocerebellum plays a more important role in voluntary movement rather than equilibrium. B. Servo correction of voluntary movements: The servo correction of movements, which involves the adjustment and correction of ongoing movements, is a function of the spinocerebellum, another part of the cerebellum. This region monitors and adjusts movements in real-time based on sensory feedback, ensuring that the movements are accurate. While the neocerebellum does contribute to motor control, its primary function is more focused on the planning and programming of movements rather than their correction during execution. D. Maintenance of muscle tone: The maintenance of muscle tone is mainly managed by the spinocerebellum and the brainstem, rather than the neocerebellum. The spinocerebellum helps in controlling the muscle tone necessary for posture and movement, while the neocerebellum is more concerned with the planning and execution of complex movements.

questions.text: The raphe nuclei located in lower pons and medulla secrete the following neurotransmitter-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Serotonin. The raphe nuclei, located in the lower pons and medulla, primarily secrete serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine or 5-HT). These nuclei play a key role in regulating mood, sleep, appetite, and various other functions. Serotonin release from the raphe nuclei influences a wide range of physiological processes, including mood regulation and sleep cycles. Incorrect options: A. Norepinephrine: Norepinephrine is primarily produced by neurons in the locus coeruleus, not the raphe nuclei. It plays a role in attention, arousal, and the fight-or-flight response, but it is not the neurotransmitter secreted by the raphe nuclei. B. Dopamine: Dopamine is produced by several areas in the brain, including the substantia nigra and ventral tegmental area, rather than the raphe nuclei. Dopamine is involved in movement control, reward processing, and motivation, but it is not secreted by the raphe nuclei. D. Acetylcholine: Acetylcholine is primarily associated with the cholinergic system, with major sources in the basal forebrain and brainstem. While it plays a role in muscle control and cognitive functions, it is not the neurotransmitter secreted by the raphe nuclei.

questions.text: The nucleus involved in Papez circuit is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Anterior nucleus of Thalamus. The Papez circuit is a neural circuit that is crucial for the regulation of emotional expression and memory. It involves the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, which is one of the central components of this circuit. The Papez circuit includes structures such as the hippocampus, mammillary bodies, anterior thalamic nuclei, and the cingulate gyrus, all of which contribute to the emotional and memory-related processes. Specifically, the anterior nucleus of the thalamus relays information from the mammillary bodies to the cingulate gyrus, completing the circuit. Incorrect options: A. Pulvinar: The pulvinar is a part of the thalamus but is not directly involved in the Papez circuit. It is primarily involved in visual processing and the integration of sensory information from various modalities. B. Intralaminar: The intralaminar nuclei of the thalamus play roles in regulating arousal, alertness, and attention, but they are not part of the Papez circuit. C. VPL nucleus: The ventral posterolateral nucleus (VPL) of the thalamus is involved in somatosensory processing, specifically transmitting sensory information from the body to the somatosensory cortex. It is not involved in the Papez circuit.

questions.text: Lesion in which of the following leads to sensory ataxia:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Posterior column. The posterior columns of the spinal cord carry proprioceptive information from the body to the brain. This includes sensations of touch, position, and vibration. A lesion in the posterior column leads to a loss of proprioception, which results in sensory ataxia. Sensory ataxia is characterized by uncoordinated movement due to the inability to sense the position of limbs and joints, even though the motor function remains intact. Incorrect options: B. Vermis: The vermis is part of the cerebellum and is involved in the coordination of movements, particularly those of the trunk and posture. A lesion here would cause cerebellar ataxia, which is more related to motor coordination rather than sensory input, so it does not directly lead to sensory ataxia. C. Floculo-nodular lobe: The floculo-nodular lobe of the cerebellum plays a role in balance and eye movements. Lesions in this area typically result in ataxia related to balance and vestibular dysfunction, but they do not cause sensory ataxia, which involves a loss of sensory input rather than motor coordination. D. Vestibular apparatus: The vestibular apparatus is responsible for maintaining balance and spatial orientation. Damage to the vestibular system can lead to balance disorders and vertigo, but it does not cause sensory ataxia. Sensory ataxia arises from loss of proprioceptive input, not from vestibular dysfunction.
